projects.title: Healthcare Q&A Agent System
projects.shortDescription: Multi-agent AI system for healthcare workflows with enterprise security and HIPAA compliance
projects.overview: Built a multi-agent system using Gemini 2.5 Flash + Google ADK for AI triage, insurance checks, and scheduling. The system integrates with FastAPI, Vertex AI, and GKE, implementing JWT authentication, PII redaction, audit logs, and HITL (Human-in-the-Loop) review pipeline with semantic matching via vector databases.
useCases: AI-powered patient triage and symptom checking
Automated insurance verification and eligibility checks
Multi-agent orchestration for complex healthcare workflows

architecture.summary: Multi-agent architecture with 4+ specialized agents, each handling specific healthcare domains. Built on Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) with FastAPI backend, integrated with Vertex AI for LLM capabilities. Implements OAuth2/JWT authentication, role-based access control, and comprehensive audit logging.
keyDecisions: Used Gemini 2.5 Flash for cost efficiency while maintaining quality
Implemented HITL pipeline for safety and compliance in healthcare context
Vector database integration for semantic matching and context retrieval
Multi-agent orchestration pattern for complex workflow coordination

metrics.compliance: HIPAA compliant with zero security incidents

challenges: Ensuring HIPAA compliance while maintaining system performance
Managing PII (Personally Identifiable Information) with proper redaction and encryption
Orchestrating multiple AI agents with proper context sharing and state management
Implementing real-time analytics while maintaining data privacy
solutions: Implemented PII redaction pipeline that automatically identifies and redacts sensitive information before processing
Used encryption at rest and in transit for all healthcare data
Created a centralized agent orchestrator that manages context and state across all agents
Built a semantic matching system using vector databases to improve context retrieval and reduce latency
results: Successfully deployed production system handling healthcare workflows with 99.9% uptime
Reduced manual processing time by 60% through automated agent workflows
Achieved HIPAA compliance with zero security incidents
Improved patient satisfaction scores by 35% through faster response times
learnings: Multi-agent systems require careful orchestration and context management to avoid conflicts
Healthcare compliance (HIPAA) requires security-first design from the ground up
Vector databases are powerful for semantic search but require careful embedding strategy
HITL pipelines are essential for AI systems in regulated industries

projects.title: PlayGround App
projects.shortDescription: Real-time social mobile app with 2,000+ weekly active users, featuring OAuth logins, real-time chat, and geo-maps
projects.overview: Built end-to-end mobile features including OAuth logins, real-time chat/events, and geo-maps using React Native and Firebase. Achieved 30% faster UI rendering and sub-200ms image uploads. Engineered robust push notification, chat persistence, and location-sharing features for over 2,000 weekly active users.
useCases: Event creation and discovery with geolocation

architecture.summary: React Native cross-platform mobile application with Firebase backend. Uses Firestore for real-time data synchronization, Firebase Authentication for OAuth, and Cloud Messaging for push notifications. Implements offline-first architecture with local caching and background sync.
keyDecisions: Chose React Native for cross-platform development (iOS and Android)
Firebase for rapid development and real-time capabilities
Offline-first architecture for poor connectivity scenarios
Image compression on client side to reduce upload times

challenges: Achieving fast UI rendering on lower-end mobile devices
Optimizing image uploads to be under 200ms while maintaining quality
Handling real-time synchronization conflicts when multiple users update simultaneously
Managing offline scenarios and ensuring data consistency when connectivity is restored
solutions: Optimized React Native components with memoization and lazy loading to reduce render times by 30%
Implemented image compression on the client side before upload, reducing file sizes by 70%
Used Firestore's conflict resolution strategies and timestamp-based ordering for real-time sync
Created offline queue system that stores operations locally and syncs when connectivity is restored
results: Achieved 30% faster UI rendering through optimization techniques
Reduced image upload time to sub-200ms with compression and optimization
Grew to 2,000+ weekly active users with stable performance
Maintained 99.5% message delivery rate even with intermittent connectivity
Achieved 4.5+ star rating on both iOS and Android app stores
learnings: Offline-first architecture is essential for mobile apps, especially in areas with poor connectivity
Image optimization can dramatically improve user experience and reduce bandwidth costs
Real-time synchronization requires careful conflict resolution strategies
Performance optimization on mobile requires profiling and testing on real devices

projects.title: Code Review Agent
projects.shortDescription: AI-powered automated code review tool reducing PR review time by 40% using FastAPI, OpenAI, and GitHub Actions
projects.overview: Developed automated code review tool using FastAPI, OpenAI & React to streamline PR analysis and boost team efficiency. Implemented context-aware comment generation and integration with GitHub Actions, cutting average PR review turnaround time by 40% while maintaining quality standards.
useCases: Automated code review for pull requests

architecture.summary: FastAPI backend with OpenAI GPT-4 integration for code analysis. React dashboard for reviewing AI-generated comments. Integrated with GitHub API and GitHub Actions for seamless CI/CD workflow. Implements intelligent prompt engineering for consistent, high-quality review comments.
keyDecisions: OpenAI GPT-4 for advanced code understanding
GitHub Actions integration for automated workflow
Context-aware prompt system for useful suggestions

metrics.security: 25% more vulnerabilities caught compared to manual reviews
metrics.efficiency: Reduced reviewer fatigue and improved developer satisfaction

challenges: Generating context-aware comments that are actually useful, not generic
Integrating with GitHub API and handling rate limits efficiently
Balancing between too many comments (noise) and too few (missing issues)
Ensuring AI suggestions don't override human judgment but enhance it
solutions: Developed context-aware prompt system that analyzes code diff, related files, and commit messages
Implemented intelligent batching and caching to reduce API calls and improve response times
Created configurable sensitivity levels allowing teams to adjust comment frequency
Built human-in-the-loop workflow where AI suggests comments but humans approve them
results: Reduced average PR review turnaround time by 40%
Improved code quality consistency across the team
Caught 25% more security vulnerabilities compared to manual reviews
Reduced reviewer fatigue and improved developer satisfaction
Enabled faster development cycles with quicker feedback loops
learnings: AI code review tools are most effective when they augment human reviewers, not replace them
Context is crucial for useful AI suggestions - generic comments are worse than no comments
Prompt engineering requires iteration and testing with real codebases
GitHub API rate limits require careful management and caching strategies

projects.title: NovaMart - Event-Driven Commerce Platform
projects.shortDescription: Walmart/Amazon-style ecommerce platform on AWS EKS with Terraform IaC, featuring event-driven microservices architecture
projects.overview: Designed a Walmart/Amazon-style ecommerce system on AWS using Dockerized microservices on EKS with Terraform IaC. Built product and order services in Spring Boot, recommendation and inventory services in Python, with comprehensive unit testing for reliability. Used DynamoDB for inventory, AWS RDS for orders, S3 for media storage, and AWS Cognito for secure authentication.

architecture.summary: Event-driven microservices architecture on AWS EKS. Product and order services built with Spring Boot, recommendation and inventory services in Python. Infrastructure-as-code with Terraform for reproducible deployments. Uses DynamoDB for high-throughput inventory, RDS for transactional orders, S3 for media, and Kafka for event-driven communication.
keyDecisions: Event-driven architecture for scalability and loose coupling
Terraform for infrastructure-as-code and reproducible deployments
Microservices with clear service boundaries using Domain-Driven Design
Saga pattern for distributed transactions across services

challenges: Designing microservices boundaries that minimize coupling while maintaining consistency
Managing distributed transactions across multiple services (e.g., order creation and inventory update)
Handling eventual consistency in event-driven systems
Scaling different services independently based on load patterns
solutions: Used Domain-Driven Design (DDD) principles to identify service boundaries and ownership
Implemented Saga pattern for distributed transactions, using events to coordinate multi-step processes
Designed event sourcing for critical workflows to ensure auditability and consistency
Created auto-scaling policies for each service based on CPU, memory, and custom metrics
results: Achieved 99.99% uptime with distributed architecture and redundancy
Scaled to handle 10,000+ concurrent users with sub-200ms response times
Reduced deployment time by 40% through infrastructure-as-code
Enabled zero-downtime deployments with blue-green deployment strategy
Improved inventory accuracy to 99.9% through event-driven updates
Reduced infrastructure costs by 30% through efficient resource allocation
learnings: Microservices architecture requires careful service boundary design - too small creates overhead, too large defeats the purpose
Event-driven systems are powerful but require careful handling of eventual consistency
Infrastructure-as-code is essential for managing complex microservices deployments
Distributed systems require comprehensive testing strategies including contract testing
Monitoring and observability become critical in microservices - you need to know what's happening everywhere
